questions.text: According to WHO 2022 classification, which of the following is not a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm?
questions.solution:
Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is a lymphoid neoplasm. It is not a myeloproliferative neoplasm.

Myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPN) are a group of disorders that cause an increased number of red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets. According to 5th edition WHO classification (2022), myeloproliferative neoplasms consist of the following:

  • Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)
  • Polycythemia vera (PV)
  • Primary myelofibrosis (PMF)
  • Essential thrombocythemia
  • Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML)
  • Chronic neutrophilic leukemia (CNL)
  • Chronic eosinophilic leukemia
  • Myeloproliferative neoplasm, not otherwise specified

questions.text: What is the most common myeloproliferative neoplasm?
questions.solution:
The most common myeloproliferative neoplasm is polycythemia vera. 

It is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder that is characterized by uncontrolled proliferation of the red blood cells in the body. It is also frequently associated with an increase in white blood cells and platelets.

questions.text:
During a routine health checkup, the following lab reports were obtained for a young male patient. What will be your next step in the evaluation?

Hb: 17 g/dl

TLC: 5500 /μL

Platelets: 1,69,000 /μL
questions.solution:
This patient has increased Hb and normal WBCs and platelets. The next step is to measure RBC mass to evaluate for polycythemia.

A person has to be evaluated for polycythemia if there is:

  • Increased hemoglobin: >16.5 g/dL in men or >16.0 g/dL in women, (or)
  • Increased hematocrit: >49 percent in men or >48 percent in women

This condition is due to either a true increase in the number of RBCs (absolute polycythemia) or an apparent increase due to a decrease in the plasma volume (relative polycythemia). Both of these conditions can be differentiated by measuring RBC mass (amount of total blood volume that is occupied by RBCs).

In patients with absolute polycythemia, erythropoietin (EPO) levels must be measured.

  • Primary polycythemia - low or normal EPO levels
  • Secondary polycythemia - elevated EPO levels

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is found to have a hemoglobin level of 18 g/dl, a hematocrit of 54%, and an elevated erythropoietin level. Which of the following is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Polycythemia vera is associated with low or normal erythropoietin (EPO) levels.

Polycythemia refers to an increase in the number of red blood cells (RBC) in the body. It is classified as:

  Primary polycythemia (polycythemia vera) Secondary polycythemia
Pathophysiology Caused by mutations in the hematopoietic stem cells

Hypoxia (COPD, carbon monoxide poisoning) 

Autonomous EPO production 
Erythropoietin (EPO) Normal or low High
WBCs, and platelet count  High (due to increased production of all cell lines) Normal

Autonomous production of erythropoietin occurs in renal cell carcinoma (RCC), hepatocellular carcinoma, cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

Relative (spurious) polycythemia refers to an apparent increase in RBC or hemoglobin count due to a decrease in the plasma volume. It is commonly seen in dehydration.

Or

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

questions.text: What is the most common cytogenetic abnormality in patients with polycythemia vera?
questions.solution:
The most common cytogenetic abnormality in polycythemia vera is the JAK2 mutation. 

JAK2 mutations can be found in the following neoplasms:

  • Polycythemia vera
  • Essential thrombocythemia
  • Primary myelofibrosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements about polycythemia vera is true?

choices.text: Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis
Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation
It is protective against H.pylori infection
Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality

questions.solution:
Generalized pruritus seen in polycythemia vera (PV) is a consequence of the activation of mast cells by JAK 2 mutation.

Other options:

Option A: The risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with erythrocytosis, not the degree of thrombocytosis.

Option C: In polycythemia vera, there is an increased risk of H.pylori infection.

Option D: Thrombosis is the major cause of mortality in polycythemia vera. The incidence of acute leukemia in patients not exposed to chemotherapy or radiation therapy is low.

PV is a clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder in which red cells, granulocytes & platelets accumulate in the absence of a physiological stimulus. The most common mutation seen in PV is the JAK2 mutation.

Clinical features of polycythemia vera are:

  • Thrombosis is the most common manifestation and is the major cause of mortality. Uncontrolled erythrocytosis causes increased viscosity of the blood causing thrombosis of the vessels. Patients may present with stroke, transient ischemic attacks, myocardial infarction, and Budd-Chiari syndrome.
  • Aquagenic pruritis is generalized itching following a warm bath or a shower due to increased mast cells and histamine.
  • Erythromelalgia is erythema and pain in the fingers, hands, and feet due to increased platelet stickiness.
  • Splenomegaly due to increased destruction of RBCs in the spleen
  • Gout is due to the excessive proliferation of the marrow cells leading to elevated uric acid levels.

questions.text: Which of the following would not be seen in patients with polycythemia vera?
questions.solution:
Low WBC count is not a feature of polycythemia vera. It is associated with an elevated WBC count.

Common laboratory findings of polycythemia vera are:

  • Elevated hemoglobin concentration, hematocrit levels, and RBC count
  • Elevated WBCs and platelet counts
  • Low to normal erythropoietin levels
  • Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a 1-month history of severe itching every time he takes a hot shower. He also reports a burning sensation in his fingers and frequent headaches. His hemoglobin is 18 g/dL and his EPO levels are low. Which of the following can provide symptomatic relief in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of polycythemia vera. In these patients, ruxolitinib, a Janus-kinase inhibitor is used to provide symptomatic relief. 

The treatment of polycythemia vera is as follows:

  • Therapeutic phlebotomy - definitive treatment
  • Anticoagulants - in patients with thrombosis
  • Symptomatic relief:
    • Ruxolitinib
    • Hydroxyurea
    • Interferon-alpha
    • PUVA therapy

questions.text: You are a first-year medicine resident. While examining a patient, you note that his spleen is enlarged 8.5 cm below his costal margin. You would include all of the following in your differential diagnosis except:
questions.solution:
Enlargement of the spleen > 8 cm below the costal margin or weight > 1000 g is called massive splenomegaly. It is not a feature of essential thrombocythemia (ET), as it causes only mild splenomegaly.

The causes of massive splenomegaly include:

  • Chronic myeloid leukemia
  • Primary myelofibrosis
  • Polycythemia vera
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
  • Lymphoma
  • Hairy cell leukemia
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

ET is a neoplasm in which the body produces too many platelets, resulting in a platelet count > 4.5 lakhs/μL. It occurs due to the mutations in the JAK2, CALR, or MPL genes.

The majority of the patients are asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally. Some patients may present with thrombotic events or rarely, hemorrhages. The following findings are seen:

  • Peripheral smear - abnormally large platelets
  • Bone marrow biopsy - increased number of megakaryocytes, with hyperlobulated nuclei

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, who was diagnosed with essential thrombocythemia, is being planned for cytoreductive therapy. What first-line drug should she be started on?
questions.solution:
The first-line drug for cytoreductive therapy in patients with essential thrombocythemia is hydroxyurea.

Treatment of essential thrombocythemia is as follows:

  • No symptoms or risk of thrombosis:
    • Observation alone
    • Low dose aspirin may be considered
  • High risk of thrombosis (cardiovascular risk factors, prior history of thrombosis)
    • Low dose aspirin
    • Cytoreduction with hydroxyurea, busulfan, or interferon-alpha

questions.text: A 60-year-old man was referred with severe anemia and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear showed teardrop cells, nucleated RBCs, and giant abnormal platelets. Bone marrow aspirate could not be obtained despite multiple attempts, hence a bone marrow biopsy was done. The findings are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the deposition of numerous collagen fibers in the bone marrow, which indicates marrow fibrosis. These clinical findings and history of a dry tap on bone marrow aspiration are diagnostic of primary myelofibrosis.

In this condition, the neoplastic proliferation of hematopoietic stem cells results in increased and abnormal proliferation of the megakaryocytes. These megakaryocytes release excessive amounts of platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and TGF-β. Increased growth factors lead to the deposition of collagen in the bone marrow which eventually leads to fibrosis. 

The clinical features include:

  • Early phase:
    • Thrombocytosis (large, abnormal platelets) and leukocytosis
    • Hypercellularity of bone marrow
  • Late phase:
    • Pancytopenia 
    • Hypocellularity and fibrosis of bone marrow (dry tap)
    • Teardrop-shaped RBCs and leukoerythroblastosis (premature release of nucleated erythroid and early granulocytes into blood)
  • Hepatosplenomegaly - due to extramedullary hematopoiesis.

The FDA approved fedratinib, a JAK2-selective inhibitor for the treatment of adult patients with intermediate or high-risk primary or secondary myelofibrosis.

questions.text: Bone marrow aspirate of a patient with pancytopenia revealed a hypercellular marrow. Which of the following conditions is unlikely?
questions.solution:
Fanconi anemia results in pancytopenia with hypocellular bone marrow. Hence, it is not likely in this patient.

Causes of pancytopenia with hypocellular bone marrow include:

  • Inherited aplastic anemia
    • Fanconi anemia
    • Dyskeratosis congenita
    • Shwachman-Diamond syndrome
  • Acquired aplastic anemia

Causes of pancytopenia with hypercellular bone marrow include:

  • Primary bone marrow disorders
    • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)
    • Myelodysplastic syndrome
    • Myelofibrosis
  • Systemic diseases
    • Megaloblastic anemia
    • Alcoholism
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Tuberculosis
    • Brucellosis

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient with the following exam findings is found to have pancytopenia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is dyskeratosis congenita. This condition is characterized by pancytopenia along with the clinical triad of:

  1. Reticular skin pigmentation 
  2. Nail dystrophy
  3. Oral leukoplakia 

 

Option A: Fanconi anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by pancytopenia, congenital anomalies, and an increased risk of malignancies.

Option B: Shwachman-Diamond syndrome presents with bone marrow failure and exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.

Option C: Diamond-Blackfan syndrome presents with low RBC counts due to congenital erythroid aplasia.

Note: Fanconi anemia is different from Fanconi syndrome. Fanconi syndrome is a disorder of renal tubular function (type 2 RTA) that results in increased excretion of glucose, amino acids, bicarbonates, and phosphates.

questions.text: All of the following can cause acquired aplastic anemia except:
questions.solution:
Herpes simplex infection is not a cause of acquired aplastic anemia.

Secondary causes of acquired aplastic anemia include:

  • Radiation
  • Toxins - Benzene
  • Drugs 
    • Chemotherapy drugs (including cyclophosphamide)
    • Sulfonamides
    • Chloramphenicol
  • Infections: 
    • 1-2 months after an attack of seronegative viral hepatitis
    • HIV, EBV, CMV
    • Parvovirus B19
  • Eosinophilic fasciitis
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria 
  • Graft vs host disease

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady is being evaluated for recurrent epistaxis. On examination, the spleen is not palpable. Investigations reveal Hb of 6 g/dL, platelet count of 18,000/μL, and WBC count of 3000/μL. The results of a bone marrow biopsy are given below. What is the best method of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical and laboratory findings, as well as bone marrow hypocellularity are diagnostic of aplastic anemia. In this young patient, the best method of management is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

Aplastic anemia presents with pancytopenia and resulting bleeding manifestations, anemia, and frequent infections. Bone marrow biopsy reveals hypocellularity with fatty infiltration of the bone marrow. The management is as follows:

  • Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation - best method of management in young patients
  • Antithymocyte globulin with cyclosporine - elderly patients and patients without HLA-matched donors
  • Eltrombopag - a thrombopoietin analog used as add-on therapy

questions.text: What is the most common cytogenetic abnormality seen in patients with myelodysplastic neoplasm?
questions.solution:
The most common cytogenetic abnormality seen in myelodysplastic neoplasm is the 5q deletion. 

Myelodysplastic syndromes/neoplasm (MDS) are a group of disorders in which abnormal stem cells produce increased numbers of immature blood cells. These immature cells are defective and die prematurely resulting in lower numbers of mature blood cells. It is characterized by pancytopenia and a high risk of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

The cytogenetic abnormalities identified in this condition include:

  • 5q deletion
  • 3q deletion
  • 7q deletion
  • Monosomy 7
  • Monosomy 5

5th edition WHO Classification of MDS (2022):

1. MDS with defining genetic abnormalities:

  • MDS with a low blast and isolated 5q deletion (MDS-5q): <5% blasts in the bone marrow or <2% blasts in the peripheral blood. 
  • MDS with a low blast and SF3B1 mutation (MDS-SF3B1): Detection of ≥15% ring sideroblasts may substitute for SF3B1 mutation.  
  • MDS with biallelic TP53 inactivation (MDS-biTP53): <20% blasts in the bone marrow or peripheral blood.

2. MDS, morphologically defined:

  • MDS with low blasts: <5% blasts in the bone marrow or <2% blasts in the peripheral blood. 
  • MDS-hypoplastic: ≤25% bone marrow cellularity
  • MDS with increased blasts (IB):
    • MDS-IB1: 5–9% of blasts in bone marrow or 2–4% in peripheral blood
    • MDS-IB2:10-19% of blasts in bone marrow or 5-19% in peripheral blood or Auer rods
  • MDS-fibrosis: 5-19% of blasts in bone marrow or 2–19% in peripheral blood

3. Childhood myelodysplastic neoplasm:

  • Childhood MDS with low blasts:<5% blasts in the bone marrow or <2% blasts in the peripheral blood
  • Childhood MDS with increased blasts: 5-19% blasts in the bone marrow or 2-19% blasts in the peripheral blood.

Related Pearl: Bone Marrow Changes in Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS)

The myelodysplastic syndrome can lead to dysplasia of the erythroid series, myeloid series, and megakaryocytes.

Dysplasia of erythroid series:

  • Megaloblastoid maturation - Abnormally large erythroid cells
  • Nuclear budding abnormalities - Nucleus with abnormal shape
  • Ring sideroblasts - Erythroblasts with stainable iron in the cytoplasm 

 

Dysplasia of myeloid series:

  • Neutrophils with a decreased number of secondary granules
  • Pseudo-Pelger-Hüet cells- neutrophils with only two nuclear lobes

 

Dysplasia of the megakaryocytes:

  • Megakaryocyte with single nuclear lobe
  • Pawn ball megakaryocytes- cells with multiple separate nuclei

If only one lineage is affected, then it is called single lineage dysplasia. If multiple lineages are affected, then it is called multilineage dysplasia. If the percentage of ring sideroblasts is more than 15% it is called MDS with ring sideroblasts (MDS-RS).

questions.text: A patient with myelodysplastic syndrome was found to have 5q deletion. What is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Lenalidomide is the drug of choice in patients with myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) associated with 5q deletion.

It is a thalidomide derivative with the following benefits in these patients:

  • Patients achieve transfusion independence
  • Normal or near-normal hemoglobin levels
  • Normalization of cytogenetics 

Adverse effects include:

  • Myelosuppression (worsening thrombocytopenia and neutropenia, necessitating blood count monitoring) 
  • Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism

However, hematopoietic stem cell transplant remains the definitive treatment.

The FDA recently approved a combination of decitabine, a nucleoside metabolic inhibitor, and cedazuridine, a cytidine deaminase inhibitor, for the treatment of adult patients with myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) and chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML).
